title: Advancing Teaching & Learning Scholars (ATLS)
description: A dynamic professional development program to help faculty understand UD and the campus systems and resources for driving student success in and around the Ryan C. Harris Learning Teaching Center.

splash.title: Advancing Teaching & Learning Scholars (ATLS)
splash.alttext: A smiling instructor calls on one of multiple students, whose hands are raised, while remote students look on via a Zoom call.
splash.text: A dynamic professional development program to help faculty understand UD and the campus systems and resources for driving student success in and around the Ryan C. Harris Learning Teaching Center.

paragraphs: The Advancing Teaching & Learning Scholars Program (ATLS) was launched by the LTC in 2022 to support faculty in advancing the University of Dayton’s Marianist teaching mission. Education in the Marianist spirit is a sacred duty for us all and, if done well, positions our graduates to become the lifelong learners that we want them to be and that our world needs.

The core ATLS program comprises eight sessions designed to introduce instructors to campus resources, pedagogy strategies, and timely teaching topics to increase teaching and learning effectiveness for instructors and students. These engaging 90-minute, in-person sessions are delivered by UD’s expert instructors and staff and ATLS sessions and may be taken in any order.

1. Increase faculty knowledge about UD students and their learning needs, campus resources, and teaching strategies
  2. Expose faculty to services and people within the LTC as a support center for their continuing professional development at UD
  3. Connect faculty with one another and key campus colleagues to build communities of practice and commitment to the institution
See graduates of the ATLS Program

badges.title: Attended Your First Session
badges.description: Well, that was easy. You attended your first ATLS program CORE session, so we only felt that it was appropriate to reward you with your first badge! You probably thought that the only thing you'd get from your first session was some useful information to help you become a better instructor, didn't you? Congratulations!

badges.title: Reflective Practitioner
badges.description: Your dedication and participation didn't stop when the session ended. You took the time to provide feedback on how it went, helping the facilitators see what resonated the most, and if anything needs to be refined for future offerings. That's super generous of you!

badges.title: Halfway There!
badges.description: It seems like just yesterday you attended your first ATLS session. Now, you're at four. Where has the time gone? This badge symbolizes your continued dedication to learning more about finding success with students, teaching, and the University of Dayton. Keep it up!

badges.title: Core Program Graduate
badges.description: This badge is a biggie. It is proof that you've completed all eight of the ATLS program CORE sessions. This is no small accomplishment and is not something you check off the list in an afternoon.

badges.title: Feedback All-Star
badges.description: Not only did you attend all of the sessions. You also provided feedback after each session in order to earn this badge. We are incredibly proud of you for completing the program, but we're also so thankful for all of the feedback you've provided along the way - ensuring a better program for everyone behind you. That's how we all get better.

modules.title: Who Are Our Students?
modules.description: Whether you’ve taught elsewhere for many years or are joining the professorial ranks for the first time, a key to being effective in helping students learn is understanding who our students are. In this session we will give you a sense of the Gen Z student in general, and more specifically, the population of students who call UD home. We will host a panel of UD students and give you the opportunity to ask them questions, and we will explore strategies for getting to know your students. Regardless of the setting for your course(s), whether required courses in large sections, upper level small seminars, graduate seminars, and more, you will get the chance to explore strategies for understanding and therefore connecting with our students.
modules.imagealt: Students looking at smiling at eachother.
learningoutcomes: Describe the demographic makeup of the UD student population.
Identify common student perceptions and expectations of a UD education.
Assess the impact of the cultural, pandemic, and social life experiences that students bring to the classroom.
Explain the importance of understanding the whole student experience in the design and facilitation of learning.

discussions.title: ATLS Core 1 - Who Are Our Students?

modules.title: Supporting Students In and Beyond the Classroom
modules.description: Supporting today’s UD students goes way beyond simply providing academic support and office hours to make sure they do well in your classes. As our view of support has evolved over the years so has our network of support resources for students. This session will cover not just what support resources are available for our students but will more broadly cover how to create an accessible and equitable learning environment for all students. Participants will also learn how to engage various offices to activate support resources as well as the basics of facilitating accommodation requests from the Office of Learning Resources.
modules.imagealt: Two people on a Zoom call. One on the screen virtually and one in person.
learningoutcomes: Create an accessible and equitable learning environment for all students.
Identify support resources available to students.
Explain how to facilitate student accommodation requests.
Engage the Office of Learning Resources for assistance & support.

discussions.title: ATLS Core 2 - Supporting Students In and Beyond the Classroom

modules.title: Using Educational Technologies at UD to Support Learning
modules.description: So many learning technologies and so little time! Participants at this session will see student testimonials about their expectations for instructor usage of technologies like Isidore, Warpwire, Zoom, and more. We will recommend best practices with ed tech based on student feedback, and we will invite participants to learn by collaborating with the Center for Online Learning.
modules.imagealt: A person smiling and seated being filmed by another person looking past the camera at the subject.
learningoutcomes: Access the learning technology systems available to support students.
Discuss the student expectations surrounding learning technology at UD.
Explain the learning and teaching benefits of using learning technology.
Engage the Center for Online Learning for assistance & support.

discussions.title: ATLS Core 3 - Using Educational Technologies at UD to Support Learning

modules.title: Driving Student Success
modules.description: Participants will understand the importance of advising/mentoring the whole student (and what that looks like). They will also be provided tools and resources to use to help mentor students through their academic journey, including technology and interpersonal strategies and techniques.
modules.imagealt: A person looking at a computer screen giving two thumbs up.
learningoutcomes: Explain the influential role faculty play in student success.
Use campus systems to support and strengthen student achievement & wellness.
Outline the benefits of advising & mentoring students.

modules.title: Engaging Students in a Learner-Centered Classroom
modules.description: This session will allow participants to share and discuss practical strategies to incorporate learner-centered activities in their courses. We will also address common challenges faced by underrepresented instructors and students.
modules.imagealt: An instructor gesturing in front of a class of students.
learningoutcomes: Plan courses that create reflective, engaged, and motivated students.
Design inclusive courses to engage a diverse range of students.

discussions.title: ATLS Core 5 - Engaging Students in a Learner-Centered Classroom

modules.title: How Do You Know If Students Are Learning?
modules.description: Assessment of student learning is frequently cited as a bane of teaching.  Despite the bad rap, gauging learning is critical for students to improve their study methods and just as critical for teachers to adjust pedagogical approaches and provide personalized feedback to students.  This session explores assessment from the perspectives of different disciplines with an eye to employing more joyful, effective and efficient assessment practices in your classes.
modules.imagealt: A person smiling while writing on a white board.
learningoutcomes: Recognize the importance of assessing student learning.
Apply backward design principles to ensure learning goals are supported & evaluated.
Recognize the role different kinds of assessment can play in facilitating learning.
Design assessment strategies that create reflective, engaged, and motivated students.

discussions.title: ATLS Core 6 - How Do You Know If Students Are Learning?

modules.title: Inclusive Pedagogy
modules.description: Utilizing principles of backward design and UD’s diversity as an institutional learning goal (ILG), this session will introduce the basic tenets of inclusive pedagogy. The goal of this session is to guide attendees in the design of course goal objectives, materials, and approaches to instruction and content delivery.
modules.imagealt: An instructor smiling and pointing to a student with their hand raised.
learningoutcomes: Identify teaching strategies and practices to promote an inclusive classroom environment.
Recognize resources to adapt learning materials to diverse populations and perspectives.
Identify universal design principles and resources in the creation of inclusive course materials.
Become familiar with principles to design learning activities that are equitable and accessible to all students.

modules.title: Why Do We Teach?
modules.description: In this session we will examine how we define our roles as teachers, why we entered the profession, what our professional goals are, and how we might attain them. Topics addressed will include vocational discernment, the purposes higher education serves today, and the scholarship of teaching and learning. The session will involve reflective writing exercises and peer discussion.
modules.imagealt: An instructor smiling and interacting with two students who are seated at a table.
learningoutcomes: Reflect on your vocation as a teacher.
Explain the crucial role of education in advancing society.
Develop a professional development plan.
Recognize the scholarly options involved in the scholarship of teaching.

discussions.title: ATLS Core 8 - Why Do We Teach?

modules.title: Teaching at the Intersection of Expectations and Flexibility
modules.description: In this engaging session, faculty will explore the art of balancing expectations and flexibility in teaching. Discover effective strategies for setting and communicating expectations, gaining student buy-in, and empowering them to take ownership of their learning. Dive into the nuanced decisions of when to provide support, establish boundaries, and navigate the fine line between flexibility and firmness, creating a dynamic and collaborative educational experience.
modules.imagealt: An instructor smiling and interacting with two students who are seated at a table.
learningoutcomes: Develop skills to set clear expectations, communicate effectively, and secure student buy-in for an engaging learning environment.
Acquire strategies for supporting students while fostering autonomy and personal growth in the learning process.
Gain insights into effective decision-making for boundaries and flexibility, optimizing the learning experience for faculty and students alike.

modules.title: Understanding the Value, Challenges, and Future of Student Feedback of Teaching at UD
modules.description: Faculty are invited to delve into the significance of Student Evaluation of Teaching (SET), learn effective strategies for interpreting and utilizing the results, and gain insights into discerning and handling unhelpful comments. Additionally, get a sneak peek into the upcoming changes to the tool and name (Student Feedback Tool / SFT) for the fall semester. Don't miss this opportunity to enhance your understanding and make the most of this valuable feedback tool.
modules.imagealt: An instructor smiling and interacting with two students who are seated at a table.
learningoutcomes: Understand the importance of Student Evaluation of Teaching (SET) for ongoing improvement in faculty practices.
Apply practical strategies to interpret and use SET results effectively for enhancing teaching.
Discuss upcoming changes to the SET tool for the fall semester, encouraging creative thinking in teaching evaluation.

modules.title: Student Retention - Practices, Tips, and Sharing
modules.description: Student retention is a big topic of conversation in higher education, but what exactly does it look like, and why is it so important? Join us as we dig into the importance of retention, explore proven strategies & practical tips, and create space for attendees to share their insights and successes. UD is a community of educators committed to fostering an environment where students not only thrive but persist on their educational journey. Don't miss this opportunity to elevate your impact in promoting student retention.
modules.imagealt: An instructor smiling and interacting with two students who are seated at a table.
learningoutcomes: Articulate the importance of student retention.
List practical strategies and tips to enhance student engagement, contributing to improved retention rates.
